quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Your expedition generates dozens of critical documents: base camp permits, equipment lists, daily weather logs, climber health records, incident reports, route maps, and supply inventories. A climber asks 'Where's the emergency descent plan?' Your team searches for 30 minutes. Another climber says 'I thought we updated the route map yesterday‚Äîwhere's the new version?' The sponsor requests proof that all safety procedures were documented.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What artifact management practice is missing?

options.A: A centralized repository with clear naming, versioning, and access controls
options.B: A system to track who owns each document and when it was last updated
options.C: Archive old documents in case someone needs historical reference

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: D - All of the above are required

insights.explanation: A centralized, well-organized repository ensures team members can find documents quickly. Naming conventions and versioning prevent confusion and errors.
insights.pmbokSupport: Project documents must be organized and accessible to authorized stakeholders

insights.explanation: Each artifact needs an owner responsible for accuracy and timeliness. Version control shows what changed and when. Access control protects sensitive information.
insights.pmbokSupport: Document control ensures accuracy, traceability, and regulatory compliance

trapSection.explanation: Poor artifact management looks like documents scattered across email, drives, and laptops. That's a recipe for confusion, error, and regulatory problems.

trapTable.violation: No one knows who's responsible for accuracy; documents get stale

trapTable.option: B only - Tracking without central location
trapTable.violation: You know who owns documents, but no one can find them

checklist: Do we have a centralized document repository?
Are naming conventions clear and consistent?
Does each document have an owner?
Are access controls defined (who can read/edit)?
Are retention and archival policies documented?
patternRecognition.patternRule: Good artifact management = centralized repo + clear naming + versioning + ownership + access control + retention policy.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Project artifacts must be organized, accessible, and controlled:

rows.action: Establish centralized repository (shared drive, document management system, or tool like Confluence, Sharepoint, etc.). Define folder structure.
keyQuestions: Is it accessible to authorized people?
rows.examKeywords: Document repository, Centralized storage, Document management

rows.action: Create artifact inventory/register listing all documents: type, owner, location, version, status, retention period.
rows.examKeywords: Artifact inventory, Document register, Documentation plan

rows.action: Define naming conventions, format standards, quality criteria, and version control rules. Example: 'ProjectName-DocumentType-Version-Date.docx'
Designate owner/custodian for each artifact. Owner is responsible for accuracy, updates, and compliance. Document this responsibility.
Define who can read, edit, and approve each document. Implement permissions (public, team, restricted, confidential). Track access for compliance.
Ensure documents are easy to find and distribute. Use searchable metadata, tags, and version history. Notify stakeholders of updates.
Establish review and approval process. Verify documents are accurate, current, and meet standards before distribution.
rows.examKeywords: Quality assurance, Approval process, Document review

rows.action: Define retention periods (how long to keep), archival procedures (how to store old documents), and disposal (when to delete). Follow regulatory requirements.
keyQuestions: How long do we keep this?
rows.examKeywords: Retention policy, Archival, Regulatory compliance, Disposal

secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your project team uses: email for some documents, a shared drive for others, and personal laptops for draft files. memoryPalace.title: Memory Palace: The Base Camp Library

story.title: Managing the Expedition's Knowledge Base
story.narrative: Your base camp has a library where all critical documents must be organized so anyone can find them in an emergency...

scenes.description: Build shelves with clear sections: Safety (permits, emergency plans), Operations (equipment lists, supply inventory), Health (medical records), Finance (receipts, permits). Each section has its spot.
Create a master index: 'Emergency Descent Plan (v2.3, 2025-01-15, Owner: Lead Climber, Location: Safety shelf).' Every document in the register.
Naming rule: 'ExpeditionName-DocumentType-Version-Date.pdf' Example: 'Everest-EmergencyPlan-v2.3-2025-01-15.pdf' Everyone follows the same naming.
Each section has a librarian: Safety documents = Lead Climber, Medical = Expedition Doctor, Finance = Logistics Officer. They keep documents current.
Emergency plan? Everyone can read. Medical records? Only authorized staff. Finance receipts? Only sponsor. Access list posted at library entrance.
Index is searchable. New climbers get briefing: 'Need emergency procedures? Aisle 2, shelf 3, blue binder.' Updates announced at evening meetings.
Before filing, Librarian checks: Is this the latest version? Is owner's signature there? Does it meet standards? Only approved documents get shelved.
Old documents (previous year) go to archive storage. Keep for 2 years (regulation requirement). Documents from 2+ years ago: shred for privacy.

story.moral: Librarian **O**rganizes repo, **R**egisters artifacts, **G**overns standards, **A**ssigns ownership, **N**avigates access, **I**mplements retrieval, **Z**eros in on QA, **E**xecutes retention.
